item.title: Training in distinguishing well precedes confessional codification
item.dc:creator: lo
item.description:
The generation of “Westminster men” who succeeded them [i.e.,Thomas Cartwright (1535–1603), Dudley Fenner (c. 1558–1587), William Perkins (1558–1602), and William Ames (1576–1633)] was thoroughly trained in theological distinctions. . . . —Andrew A. Woolsey, Unity and Continuity in Covenantal Thought: A Study in the Reformed Tradition to the Westminster Assembly, (Grand Rapids, MI: Reformation Heritage …

Continue reading "Training in distinguishing well precedes confessional codification"
item.content:encoded:
The generation of “Westminster men” who succeeded them [i.e.,Thomas Cartwright (1535–1603), Dudley Fenner (c. 1558–1587), William Perkins (1558–1602), and William Ames (1576–1633)] was thoroughly trained in theological distinctions. . . .

—Andrew A. Woolsey, Unity and Continuity in Covenantal Thought: A Study in the Reformed Tradition to the Westminster Assembly,
(Grand Rapids, MI: Reformation Heritage Books, 2012), 23.
